text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- The number of people unemployed in Bulgaria rose to 512,992 or 13.4 percent of the workforce in January from 478,770 in December, the National Labour Exchange said.
-- Bulgaria's interim cabinet appointed Finance minister Svetoslav Gavriiski to head the Bank Consolidation Company, which manages state equity in Bulgarian commercial banks. @

-- Bulgaria's caretaker government set up a Structural Reform Council, headed by the deputy prime minister Alexander Bozhkov to deal with industrial sector reforms pledged to the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

-- Bulgaria's Foreign Aid Agency (FAA) is expected to return a grant of 400 tonnes of frozen beef to Switzerland on concern the meat might have infected by the "mad cow" disease, FAA director Emilia Maslarova said. @
-- Bulgaria's caretaker cabined decided a 50,000-lev note should be put in circulation by end-June as soaring inflation made a new note necessary to ease payments, the government press centre said.
-- Retail food prices in Bulgaria rose 35 percent in the past 10 days, the National Statistics Institute said.

-- There would be no reason to raise fuel prices if the lev stabilises near its current levels of 2,000 per dollar, interim prime minister Stefan Sofianski said. Prices rose by up to 178 percent on Tuesday. @

-- Bulgaria's Kozloduy nuclear power plant is vitally important for the country's economy and it should continue operating prime minister Stefan Sofianski said, referring to comments by Energy minister Georgi Stoilov that safety at Kozloduy was not meeting socially acceptable risks.
-- Bulgaria's deputy prime minister Alexander Bozhkov said that incompetent directors of state industrial plants would be sacked. @

-- Bulgarian National Bank (BNB) experts discussed a scheme for buyback of bad debt bonds at 50 to 70 percent discount from commercial banks proposed by the newly set up Financial Stabilisation Council, BNB officials said.
Those bonds were issued three years ago to cover debts of state companise to local commercial banks accumulated before 1991. -- Sofia Newsroom, (++359-2) 981 8569
